comments.commentBody: The North is by far the most beautiful part of Spain. Gijón and A Coruña are two of the most beautiful cities.

A great choice for a drink and dinner. The kitchen is very good, as is the service and choice of beers. Backyard patio in the summer is terrific. Close to the Broadview subway station for those that want a second pint.
The Knicks just rehired Isiah Thomas. Any hope anyone might have had has been crushed. No wonder Lebron wants to be in Fla. The organization is still run by idiots.
Does Thomas have something on Dolan which this hiring serves to suppress?

Ha Ha Ha Ha. I've been watching the Knicks for 30yrs and they continue to be a joke. Isiah is just the worst example of the pathetic organization that is the KNICKS. Fortunately they are not a team I root for.

He must be a GREAT interview - or have something on the Dolans. His tenure with the Knicks was (and still is) a FAILURE. Given their money, location, and criticality to the NBA the Knicks are by far the worst franchise in the league.

I love it when I read that Isaih is here to help younger players....he's never helped anyone but Isiah. Isiah = Selfish and always has.

Actually, it would have been a nice action had the Orioles given Mr. Gentile the $5,000 back in 1962 as he was so close (to the RBI lead) in any case in 1961. Then, the 5 grand would have meant something.

And, since they were cheap about it at the time, to have truly rectified the situation—to a certain extent anyway—35 or 40 grand paid to him now would have been the least they could do to erase the sting of the front office’s stinginess almost 5 decades ago. As it is, it is basically a symbolic gesture now, and another example of miserliness.

The good will the team management could have purchased right at this moment would far exceed that amount when you consider how much they pour down the drain in today's and yesteryear's dollars on players whose entire careers couldn't compare to what Jim Gentile accomplished in 1961 alone in the shadow of Messieurs Mantle and Maris. And these remarks come from a lifelong Yankee fan (born and raised in the borough of the Bombers). C’mon, Mr. MacPhail and Mr. Angelos, do something right for a change. It might ever-so-slightly take some of the sting off of how you’ve mismanaged your team, brighten up an old-timer’s golden years, and delight the O’s fans for a change. This is not the right situation in which to be cheap and mean to a representative of past great baseball accomplishments in Baltimore.

I don't know how the interest was computed or the rate of inflation, but i do know i bought my first car, a Pontiac Le Mans, for $2,970.
A navigation upgrade can cost $4,500 today...

The taxpayers of Colorado and other states who underfunded their public employee retirement accounts saved that money years ago for themselves. They did so with full knowledge that there was an obligation hanging out there. They incurred that obligation as a promise to pay public employees a lower current wage with the promise of the future benefits of the public pension plan. Taxpayers and their representatives could have chosen to tax themselves and cover the obligation little by little. Now, when the obligation is due they forget that they kept the money and try and weasel out of their debt.

The State of Wisconsin legislated a cap on teachers salaries for the past 20 years, but they have an almost fully funded state employee retirement account. Our taxpayers will not be stretched to meet the obligation because we have been pay it off over time. Why couldn't the people in Colorado have done that?
I think it's pretty amazing that you consider a call for shared sacrifice and taking a haircut on a cost of living adjustment somehow akin to Beckism.

@105 absolutely correct. That is how teacher's retirement is figured. Adding insult to injury in the equation is the issue of social security. Even if a teacher has earned the 40 credits outside of the teaching profession, they are not allowed to collect social security. Their pension is deducted from any social security they are eligible for and that works out to zero social security for teachers. I continue to work after retirement and continue to pay in to social security even though I will never be able to collect it.
There is a reason the rich folks are going after pensions and notice you are seeing the attacks in every form of media. First the pensions, then social security and finally unions. Unions have an organizational structure to fight back. During the Age of Industry unions were illegal because they 'interferred' with the profits of corporations. Those of you writing against your own best interests would do well to remember the rich will pick us off one group at a time until there is no one left to fight. Think they can't do it? Read the insane comments people leave as they parrot the talking points put out by right wing radio. As for Mr. Lieber, well you are a good little drone and like Beck you deliver the message to the masses. Just following orders?
I think it's pretty amazing that you consider a call for shared sacrifice and taking a haircut on a cost of living adjustment somehow akin to Beckism.
Roll Tide!

Nice observation Appleby seemed so clam at that stage of the proceedings. I use a yard-stick and tee the ball at 18"!  I can see the exact inches from ball to my ankles. What I discovered using it on the course was that I was often miss-aligned left.

Tiger just isn't Tiger, right now,
No roar, much more of a miaow,
Pity Westwood's right calf,
Faltered on his behalf,
He'd have plucked number one from the bough!

This minute by minute report on Westwood's movements kind of amuses me. I live in sight ot I-77, but I missed Westwood as he went by. Thanks Mr Dorman, and good luck to Westwood.

rmk

Just so you know:  most PERA retirees in Colorado are opposed to the lawsuit.  We agree with former Gov. Lamm and Senate Minority Leader Shaffer that the cost of  making PERA solvent must be shared.  It's better that we all do our part than that the system crashes.  If we are greedy, the taxpayers will revolt.

A large part of the reason textbook prices have increased, as the article states, is because the second market has become much more efficient: it is much easier to find a buyer for your used textbook now then it used to be. So to recoup costs publishers have to raise prices and increase the frequency of new editions.

I wonder how "textbook expenses" for the average student have changed over time. Of course if you buy all your texts new at the college bookstore you'll pay a pretty penny, but what about all the students that buy books used.

If you're paying $1000 a term for textbooks I would bet that you are 1) a first-term freshman, 2) v. wealthy, and/or 3) use your mom's credit card.

If you plan to work past the age at which you have preferred to retire, at least make certain that your spouse and/or children are protected by a significant amount of insurance on your life, so that they are not left only with either an unsellable business or one which they have neither the qualifications or inclination to operate in the event of your death. If you have partners, make sure that the business carries insurance on the lives of each, to have funds available to buy out the spouses of deceased partners, if necessary.

bigwords.com is the website I used to buy all of my textbooks. You can look up the ISBN number at the University bookstore and search that way. This website then searches at all the other bookselling websites for you to find the cheapest price. It saved me hundreds of dollars each semester. Just make sure you order right away when classes begin as some of the sites can take a week to deliver. Getting the book from the library can also work but it not recommended if you need it for the whole semester or need to write in it.

There is a class war being waged in this country between corporate America and the poor, and the working and middle classes.Millions of Americans working for corporations watched helplessly as their defined pension plans were eliminated and switched to 401k plans.The result is that  retirees and workers faced devastating  financial losses during the Great Recession.Now,corporate America is pitting the average American worker who no longer receives a pension through their job against the cops,teachers,firemen, and other public workers lucky enough to have a pension and blaming the state and local workers for the trillion dollar pension gap.However,the truth is that our governors and representatives  caused this trillion dollar gap because they did not fully fund the pensions even in good times.Instead,to buy votes they redirected the funding of the pensions to lower taxes or  used the money on other spending.As mentioned in the article,in many states public employees do not receive Social Security or Medicare.Not mentioned in the piece is that public employees often have to contribute to their pensions and pay for their medical insurance when they retire.In Connecticut, teachers pay 7% of their gross into the pension plan and when a teacher retires,he must pay for approximately $14,000 a year for husband and wife medical coverage.And like most other workers, public employees do not have the skills or the money to invest in the stock market and the state and local governments do not match employee contributions to 413b plans.What's so scary is that big business has eliminated pensions for its workers and now wants to do the same for public employees.Trillions for endless wars and tax cuts aimed at the wealthiest.Blank checks to bail out Wall St.Two thirds of businesses do not pay any federal taxes including obscenely profitable companies like Exxon Mobile.Billions spent on taxpayer subsidies to Big Oil and other corporate welfare programs.Yet,Ron Lieber begrudges the $2883 a month pension the Colorado teacher receives.One more point.On a teacher's salary,better yet, on the average workers' salary, there is no way that a family could save the almost $1,000,0000 needed to buy an annuity to provide a decent retirement income.Really, the workers of this country should be demanding defined pension plans from a corporate America sitting on $1.8 trillion in cash.Public and private employees need to write to their reprsentatives and speak out at town hall meetings to express their anger at the demise of the American dream.

Those of us employed get to enjoy the highs and the lows of portfolio management.
I wonder who devised a formula that says public servants win at all costs to privately employed.
We have to stop the idea that no matter what public servants don't have to suffer the consequences of a down market and people like me get to suffer a down market and then keep them at an up market and their pensions whole.

When contracts with public employees were made politicians were well aware of the costs. In good times instead of fully funding these pensions with the extra funds those funds went to pet projects that would help the politicians get reelected. Perhaps these same politicians would give up their benefit packages along with a pay cut to help fund the obligation they have to previous employees.
Once the public has a contract with someone they are obligated to pay on that contract. All the deals that politicians may have made to corporations to limit the corporations tax exposure should be rescinded to pay for the obligations the public took on.
These public employees live and spend their in the area that they earned it. By cutting these funds these retired employees will cut back on their spending and cause businesses to close.
There are too many problems that arise but the most important thought is that once you make a promise you are obligated to keep it.

Indeed, this is class war. The wealthy business class attempting to pit the middle classes against one another to maintain their privilege. Let us all have to work 'til we drop so they can have their billions. The answer is that all workers should have adequate pensions- not none of them. Those of you bashing unions should rather fight to form one. Otherwise the march towards plutocracy will continue unabated.

How about those professors who require students to buy the books they have authored??
They are guaranteed to have a captive market.
Always seemed shady and borderline unethical to me.

I am entering my fourth year of college and by now I have the art of buying textbooks down to an art. Try to avoid the university bookstores at all cost, and I often cut corners and buy older editions of a book. My first stop is always alibris.com followed by half.com. This semester I am carrying 17 credits, and I only spent 55 dollars on books (granted, I am not taking any hard sciences or math). One of the best resources I have found for cheap books is the student book exchange that takes place on our campus at the beginning of every semester. A student group organizes the sale - they just keep a 10% commission. I often go and just browse for my own personal collection -- people are always desperate to sell their old English books, so I get a lot of the classics for $2 each!

All I know is everyone wants more money. I can't help but juxtapose these comments against the big bonuses Goldman Sachs, et al. were OBLIGATED to pay to their, uh, employees.

One thing is true. Retirees, it is up to YOU to fight for what YOU deserve. We are our own government and WE get what WE deserve.
